title: Seaborn Example
text:
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

# Sample data
data = {
    'Category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
    'Values': [23, 45, 56, 78]
}
df = pd.DataFrame(data)

# Create a barplot
sns.set(style="whitegrid")  # Optional: Set a clean grid style
plt.figure(figsize=(8, 6))  # Set the figure size
sns.barplot(data=df, x='Category', y='Values', palette='viridis')

# Customize the plot
plt.title("Bar Plot Example", fontsize=16)
plt.xlabel("Category", fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel("Values", fontsize=12)

# Show the plot
plt.show()

Passing `palette` without assigning `hue` is deprecated and will be removed in v0.14.0. Assign the `x` variable to `hue` and set `legend=False` for the same effect.

title: Starwars
text:
Let’s analyze the starwars data:
starwars <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/starwars.csv")

title: Starwars
text:
Variable Description for starwars data.frame
The following describes the variables in the starwars data.frame.

films List of films the character appeared in
name Name of the character
species Name of species
height Height (cm)
mass Weight (kg)
hair_color, skin_color, eye_color Hair, skin, and eye colors
birth_year Year born (BBY = Before Battle of Yavin)
sex The biological sex of the character, namely male, female, hermaphroditic, or none (as in the case for Droids).
gender The gender role or gender identity of the character as determined by their personality or the way they were programmed (as in the case for Droids).
homeworld Name of homeworld

title: Starwars
text:
Human vs. Droid

ggplot(data = 
         starwars %>% 
         filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = species, y = mass, 
                   fill = species),
               show.legend = FALSE)

dtype: int64
Use a Seaborn to plot the distribution of pos for each of those artists
import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


# finding the artists with the top10 most tracks
top_artists = spotify['artist_name'].value_counts().head(10).index

# Filter data
top_artist_tracks = spotify[spotify['artist_name'].isin(top_artists)]
#in case there are missing values have to drop them so it will still plot
top_artist_tracks = top_artist_tracks.dropna(subset=['pos'])


# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.boxplot(data=top_artist_tracks, x='artist_name', y='pos')
From looking at this distribution of box plots, all of the top 10 artists have similar median pos distributions. With a median pos of around 30. From the boxplot we can see that all top ten artists have numerous high outliers. Drake has the largest max around 175, where Rihanna has the lowest max value near 140. Additionally from the plot it looks like Rihanna and The Weekend have the smallest IQR.

title: Data Analysis Project
text:
Salary Distribution Among Teams
Let’s start with the salary distribution among teams using seaborn for visualization. ​​


# Handle missing values in 'Salary' by replacing them with the median salary
median_salary = nba['Salary'].median()
nba['Salary'].fillna(median_salary, inplace=True)

/var/folders/_m/d6jf0jhd2zzdfd5kzdhl_24w0000gn/T/ipykernel_79892/1671011424.py:3: FutureWarning: A value is trying to be set on a copy of a DataFrame or Series through chained assignment using an inplace method.
The behavior will change in pandas 3.0. This inplace method will never work because the intermediate object on which we are setting values always behaves as a copy.

For example, when doing 'df[col].method(value, inplace=True)', try using 'df.method({col: value}, inplace=True)' or df[col] = df[col].method(value) instead, to perform the operation inplace on the original object.


  nba['Salary'].fillna(median_salary, inplace=True)



# Set the aesthetic style of the plots
sns.set_style("whitegrid")

# Calculate total salary by team
team_salary = (
    nba
    .groupby('Team')['Salary']
    .sum()
    .reset_index()
    .sort_values(by='Salary', ascending=False)
)

# Plot total salary by team
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 16))
sns.barplot(data = team_salary,
            x = 'Salary', y = 'Team',
            palette = 'coolwarm')
plt.title('Total Salary Distribution Among NBA Teams')
plt.xlabel('Total Salary')
plt.ylabel('Team')
plt.xticks(rotation=45)
plt.show()








The visualization above displays the total salary distribution among NBA teams, with teams sorted by their total salary expenditure. This bar plot reveals which teams are the biggest spenders on player salaries and which are more conservative. The color gradient provides a visual cue to easily distinguish between the higher and lower spending teams.
Notice that Portland Trail Blazers has the highest total salary followed by Golden State Warriors and Philadelphia 76ers, and Memphis Grizzlies has the lowest total salary.

title: Data Analysis Project
text:
Player Age Distribution
Next, let’s explore the Player Age Distribution across the NBA. We’ll create a histogram to visualize how player ages are distributed, which will help us understand if the league trends younger, older, or has a balanced age mix. ​​

# Convert 'Birthday' column to datetime format
from dateutil import parser
# nba['Birthday'] = nba['Birthday'].apply(lambda x: parser.parse(x))

# Now, let's calculate the age of each player
# nba['Age'] = (datetime.now() - nba['Birthday']).dt.days // 365

# Plot the age distribution of NBA players
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.histplot(nba['Age'],
             bins = 15,
             kde = True,
             color = 'skyblue')
plt.title('Age Distribution of NBA Players')
plt.xlabel('Age')
plt.ylabel('Count')
plt.show()


/Users/bchoe/anaconda3/lib/python3.11/site-packages/seaborn/_oldcore.py:1119: FutureWarning: use_inf_as_na option is deprecated and will be removed in a future version. Convert inf values to NaN before operating instead.
  with pd.option_context('mode.use_inf_as_na', True):









The histogram above shows the age distribution of NBA players, with a kernel density estimate (KDE) overlay to indicate the distribution shape. The plot helps identify the common ages for NBA players and whether there are significant numbers of very young or older players.
Notice that the majority of players fall within an age range from 24 to 34. There are few players whose age is above 40.

title: Data Analysis Project
text:
Position-wise Salary Insights
Moving on to Position-wise Salary Insights, we’ll examine how average salaries differ across player positions. This analysis could reveal which positions are typically higher-paid, potentially reflecting their value on the basketball court. Let’s create a box plot to visualize the salary distribution for each position. ​​

# Plot salary distribution by player position
plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6))
sns.boxplot(data = nba,
            x = 'Position', y = 'Salary',
            palette = 'Set2')
plt.title('Salary Distribution by Position')
plt.xlabel('Position')
plt.ylabel('Salary')
plt.show()








The box plot above illustrates the salary distribution by player position, showcasing the variation in salaries among different positions within the NBA. PG-SG has the highest median salary.

title: Data Analysis Project
text:
Top 10 Highest Paid Players
Lastly, we’ll identify the Top 10 Highest Paid Players in the NBA. Let’s visualize this information.

# Identify the top 10 highest paid players
top_10_salaries = nba.sort_values(by='Salary', ascending=False).head(10)

# Plot the top 10 highest paid players
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))
sns.barplot(data = top_10_salaries,
            x = 'Salary', y = 'PlayerName',
            palette = 'viridis')
plt.title('Top 10 Highest Paid NBA Players')
plt.xlabel('Salary')
plt.ylabel('Player')
plt.show()








The bar plot above reveals the top 10 highest-paid NBA players, showcasing those who stand at the pinnacle of the league in terms of salary. This visualization not only highlights the star players who command the highest salaries but also may reflect their marketability, performance, and contribution to their respective teams.

import pandas as pd
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt


# finding the artists with the top10 most tracks
top_artists = spotify['artist_name'].value_counts().head(10).index

# Filter data
top_artist_tracks = spotify[spotify['artist_name'].isin(top_artists)]
#in case there are missing values have to drop them so it will still plot
top_artist_tracks = top_artist_tracks.dropna(subset=['pos'])


# Plot
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 6))
sns.boxplot(data=top_artist_tracks, x='artist_name', y='pos')
From looking at this distribution of box plots, all of the top 10 artists have similar median pos distributions. With a median pos of around 30. From the boxplot we can see that all top ten artists have numerous high outliers. Drake has the largest max around 175, where Rihanna has the lowest max value near 140. Additionally from the plot it looks like Rihanna and The Weekend have the smallest IQR.

title: Python Basics
text:
Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language. This is a simple Python code:

print('Hello, World!')




In Python, variables can store data of different types without explicitly declaring the type.
For example:

integer_variable = 10
string_variable = 'Hello'
float_variable = 10.5

float_variable

10.5





Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

# Equals: a == b
# Not Equals: a != b
# Less than: a < b
# Less than or equal to: a <= b
# Greater than: a > b
# Greater than or equal to: a >= b

These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in ‘if statements’ and loops.

# if statement:
if 5 > 2:
    print('Five is greater than two!')




A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.
A function can return data as a result.

# Defining a function:
def my_function():
    print('Hello from a function')

# Calling a function:
my_function()




A list is a collection which is ordered and changeable.
A dictionary is a collection which is unordered, changeable and indexed.

# List example:
my_list = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']

# Dictionary example:
my_dict = {'name': 'John', 'age': 36}

text:
Slicing Methods
Important to remember for lists, Index Starts at 0 not
Used when you want to extract a substring from the string
In python it is left inclusive and right exlcusive
###Format [start : end : stop]
[:] –> extracts the entire list
##Bulit in Functions len() command gets the length of the string or how many elements are in a list
Dot operation:
-used to access atributes ex:
( .split, . delete, .add, .join)

#Slicing Methods practice:
# [start: end: step]
letters ='abcdeghij'
letters[4:]

'eghij'



letters[:3] #it does not include the 3rd element! its left inclusive but RIGHT EXCLUSIVE and remember index starts at 0

'abc'



#Cw 4.3
fare= "$10.00"
tip= "2.00$"
tax= "$ 0.80"

fare=fare[1:] #slicing to exclude the $
tip=tip[:-1]
tax=tax[2:]

fare = float(fare)  #type casting
tip=float(tip)
tax=float(tax)

tot=fare+tip+tax
print("the total price is", tot)

the total price is 12.8

First we found that the top 5 genres with the highest film count in this holiday movie dataset is comedy, drama, romance, family and animation.
From the scatter plot we can see that there is a postive association, in the log_num_votes and average_rating for the genres of Romance and Drama. On the other hand there is a negative association between log_num_votes and average_rating for the genres of family, comedy, and animation.
Additionally we can see for the movie type, almost about all 5 of the genres had a postive association between log_num_votes and average_rating. Where for the TvMovie type only Drama had a postive assocaition between log_num_votes and average_rating where comedy, romance, family and animation all had a negative association. For video type the data was kinda all over the place. Family, animation and comedy had steep negative assocaitons whereas romance had a postivwe assocation and drama had a zero slope best fit line suggesting not much of an assocaiton.

title: Python Basics
text:
Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language. This is a simple Python code:

print('Hello, World!')




In Python, variables can store data of different types without explicitly declaring the type.
For example:

integer_variable = 10
string_variable = 'Hello'
float_variable = 10.5

float_variable

10.5





Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
An Important thing to note is the use of =
= is an Assignment operator and NOT an equal sign
= will assign the value on the right side to the varaible on the left side.

# Equals: a == b
# Not Equals: a != b
# Less than: a < b
# Less than or equal to: a <= b
# Greater than: a > b
# Greater than or equal to: a >= b

Different Data Types:

integers ex: 10
floats ex: 8.902
strings ex: “SUNY Geneseo”
booleans ex: True, False
Nothing ex: None
List ex: [“apple”, “pear”, “orange”, “kiwi”] -lists are more useful bc they are mutable
Tuple ex: (“apple”, “pear”, “orange”, “kiwi”) -similar to lists but NOT mutable.


10 == 20
10 =='10' #comparing an int to a string
# == is checking if both sides have the same value --> Boolean Expression, T or F

False


##Operators +additon
-subtraction
*multiplication
**powers
/division
//integer division

#CW 4.1

2**5/(7*(4-2**3))

-1.1428571428571428


These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in ‘if statements’ and loops.
If statements are used for giving a result if certain condition is ture

# if statement:
if 5 > 2:
    print('Five is greater than two!')


score = 98

if score == 100:
    print("Top marks!")
elif score > 90 and score < 100:
    print("High score!")
elif score > 10 and score <= 90:
    pass
else:
    print("Better luck next time.")

High score!





A function is a block of code which only runs when it is called.
You can pass data, known as parameters, into a function.
A function can return data as a result.

# Defining a function:
def my_function():
    print('Hello from a function')

# Calling a function:
my_function()




A list is a collection which is ordered and changeable.
A dictionary is a collection which is unordered, changeable and indexed.

# List example:
my_list = ['apple', 'banana', 'cherry']

# Dictionary example:
my_dict = {'name': 'John', 'age': 36}

##List Comprehension: A concise way to create or modify lists
Syntax: [expression for item in iterable if condition]
ex: squares = [x**2 for x in range(5)]
##Dictionary Comprehension:
A consicse way to create or modify dictionaries
Syntax: {key_expression: value_expression for item in iterable if condition}
ex: squares_dict = {x: x**2 for x in range(5)}

title: Python Basics
text:
Slicing Methods
Important to remember for lists, Index Starts at 0 not
Used when you want to extract a substring from the string
In python it is left inclusive and right exlcusive
###Format [start : end : stop]
[:] –> extracts the entire list
##Bulit in Functions len() command gets the length of the string or how many elements are in a list
Dot operation:
-used to access atributes ex:
( .split, . delete, .add, .join)

#Slicing Methods practice:
# [start: end: step]
letters ='abcdeghij'
letters[4:]

'eghij'



letters[:3] #it does not include the 3rd element! its left inclusive but RIGHT EXCLUSIVE and remember index starts at 0

'abc'



#Cw 4.3
fare= "$10.00"
tip= "2.00$"
tax= "$ 0.80"

fare=fare[1:] #slicing to exclude the $
tip=tip[:-1]
tax=tax[2:]

fare = float(fare)  #type casting
tip=float(tip)
tax=float(tax)

tot=fare+tip+tax
print("the total price is", tot)

the total price is 12.8
